column1: Largo is the third largest city in Pinellas County
column3: United States as well as the fourth largest in the Tampa Bay area. As of the 2010 Census
column4: the city had a population of 77

column1: Largo was first incorporated in 1905. In 1913
column2: it became the first municipality in Pinellas County to adopt a council-manager government. It switched back and forth from "town" to "city" a few times
column3: and became a city again in 1974. It was an exporter of agricultural products until the 1960s population growth began to transform it into a bedroom community. From 1905 to 2010
column4: Largo grew in area from 9⁄16 square mile (1.5 km2) to about 19 square miles (48 km2)
column5: and in population from about 300 people to more than 70
column6: 000. Largo began as a rural farming community and became the third largest city in Florida's most densely populated county.

column1: Largo is a sister city to Tosayamada
column3: Japan. In 2007
column4: Largo was named a National Arbor Day Tree City for the 28th year in a row and is the only city in Tampa Bay that is a Sterling Tree City.

column1: The native inhabitants of the Largo area were the Tocobaga Indians. They are also known as the Safety Harbor culture from their archeological remains near present-day Safety Harbor. The Spanish came to Florida in the 16th century.  In the 18th century
column2: the Tocobaga had been virtually destroyed after years of exposure to European diseases
column3: Spanish settlement efforts and warfare between Spain and England. The Largo area
column4: like the rest of Pinellas County
column6: Spain transferred sovereignty of Florida to The United Kingdom. In 1783
column7: Florida fell to Spanish sovereignty once again until it was transferred to the United States in 1821. By 1845
column8: a surveyor recorded the location of Lake Tolulu
column9: apparently south of present-day East Bay Drive and roughly where the Largo Central Park Nature Preserve is today.

column2: homesteaders to the Largo area were the families of James and Daniel McMullen around 1852. The McMullens and other settlers raised cattle
column3: grew citrus and vegetables and fished. During the Civil War
column4: many Largo area residents fought for the Confederate States of America. James and Daniel McMullen were members of the "Cow Cavalry" driving Florida cattle to Georgia and the Carolinas to help sustain the war effort.  Other area residents served on blockade runners.  Still others left the area to serve in the Confederacy's armies. After the war
column5: Largo area residents returned to farming
column7: and raising citrus. The Orange Belt Railway reached the area in 1888. By this time Lake Tolulu had been renamed Lake Largo
column8: and residents of the community west of the lake adopted the name "Largo".

column1: The Town of Largo was incorporated in 1905. Lake Largo was drained in 1916 to make way for growth and development. Between 1910 and 1930
column2: Largo's population increased about 500%. Then and for decades afterwards
column3: Largo's economy was based on agriculture—citrus groves
column4: cattle ranches
column6: as well as turpentine stills and sawmills. Largo is best remembered as "Citrus City"
column7: from the time it was a citrus packing

column1: The Great Depression was unkind to Largo. Largo lacked the financial resources to meet its obligations.  Largo reverted to its 1913 boundaries and charter. The population dropped approximately 30%. The debt incurred by the issuance of bonds in the late 1920s was not paid off until after World War II.
The years after World War II saw rapid growth as people began moving into the area and Largo annexed surrounding lands. During the nuclear arms race
column2: electronics companies like General Electric and Honeywell boosted the economy. The population increased to about 5
column4: to about 20
column7: 000 in 2005. Largo's original area was 9/16th of a square mile. By 1982
column8: Largo had grown to about 13 square miles (34 km2) and to about 19 square miles (48 km2) in 2010. The groves
column10: ranches and forests have mostly given way to homes and shopping centers and light industry. The increased population resulted in a need for increased city services. All departments saw rapid growth and improvements in quality
column11: especially under the leadership of the late Mayor Thom Feaster. In 1995
column12: Largo Central Park opened on the site of the old Pinellas County Fairgrounds. It is the setting for the Largo Central Park Performing Arts Center and the Largo Public Library.

column2: Largo achieved two milestones furthering its former motto of "City of Progress". Democrat Patricia Gerard became the city's first female mayor. She narrowly defeated incumbent mayor Robert E. Jackson
column3: in a bitterly contested race. (Dr. Jackson had been the longest serving elected Democrat in Pinellas County.) The voters' choice between these two candidates decided the major issue of the election:  that the city would not revert to a mayor-dominated process of governance in lieu of the continuing role for the seven-member commission acting as non-partisans—that is
column4: deliberating independently and equally with the mayor and deciding democratically the political issues of the city.

column2: the city elected its first commissioner of African-American descent
column3: Rodney J. Woods
column4: in a landslide against a former commissioner.

column3: the iconic Largo Clock Tower
column4: which was constructed shortly after completion of Largo Central Park
column5: was demolished. City officials made the change because of the tower's decay and because a deteriorating landmark at a busy intersection was not an uplifting and memorable sight. The area surrounding the clock tower was replaced with a small garden area in order to incorporate the area into Largo Central Park.

column2: −82.777791). It is centrally located in Pinellas County
column3: touching the Intracoastal Waterway to the southwest and Tampa Bay to the northeast. Clearwater is Largo's neighbor to the north. To the northwest are the towns of Belleair and Belleair Bluffs. The city of Pinellas Park lies south of eastern Largo. Seminole lies south of western Largo. The unincorporated community of Ridgecrest forms a large enclave between western and central Largo. A number of county enclaves pepper the City of Largo.

column2: Largo's total area was 18.6 square miles (48.1 km2)
column3: of which 17.6 square miles (45.6 km2) was land and 0.97 square miles (2.5 km2)
column6: there were 651 acres (2.6 km2) of park lands. The city's lowest elevation is sea level. At its highest
column7: the city's elevation is about 69 feet (21 m). Largo is dotted with a number of lakes
column8: the largest of which is Taylor Lake at 53 acres (210
column9: 000 m2). Allen's Creek drains northeast Largo
column10: flowing into Tampa Bay. McKay Creek flows through southwest Largo into the Intracoastal Waterway. The McKay Creek basin is prone to flooding.

column1: Largo is located on the Pinellas Peninsula
column2: so that its climate is moderated by its proximity to the Gulf of Mexico and Tampa Bay. In the winter
column3: temperatures are warmer on the Pinellas Peninsula than on mainland Florida. Winters are generally drier than the rest of the year. Most of the rainfall comes in the summer
column4: when the sea breeze carries moisture from the Gulf inland. Largo's record low is 22 °F (−6 °C)

column1: The decline of agriculture with population growth beginning in the 1960s largely transformed Largo into a bedroom community. Electronics
column3: could not fill the gap left by agriculture. Other light manufacturers fill various niches.  The vast majority of jobs in Largo are in services and in retail sales.

column1: The health care industry continues to grow to meet the needs of an aging population. Hospitals are among the area's strongest employers. Largo Medical Center
column2: owned by the Hospital Corporation of America (HCA)
column3: was established in 1978; it consists of two separate campuses: its original campus near downtown Largo
column4: and the former Sun Coast Hospital on Indian Rocks Road
column5: which was renamed Largo Medical Center-Indian Rocks Campus after its acquisition by HCA.

column1: The City of Largo is governed by a City Commission of seven people elected at large to staggered
column2: four-year terms. The mayor acts as a member and presiding officer of the Commission. The Commission's role encompasses the setting of city policy
column3: exercising those duties imposed by the charter and law. In so doing
column4: the City Commission executes the City's powers by the passage of resolutions and ordinances. The Commission appoints and directs the City Manager and approves the City Manager's appointments for City Attorney

column1: The City Manager directs the administration in governing and providing municipal services to Largo. The Administration Department includes the City Manager's Office
column3: the City Clerk's Office
column4: the Communications and Marketing Office
column5: the Office of Management and Budget
column6: and the City Attorney.The City Manager is appointed by and answerable to the City Commission as a whole. The City of Largo is unique in that a supermajority of commissioners is required to terminate the City Manager. The City Manager appoints and supervises all department directors

column1: Pinellas County Schools operates primary and secondary schools. The school district's administrative headquarters is located in Largo. Largo's high school is Largo High
column2: and its mascot is the razorback boar. They are called the Packers because of the influence of the citrus packing industry on the town
column3: most notably
column4: the packing plant of Senator John Taylor.

column1: Largo's middle school is Largo Middle. The school colors are orange and black and the mascot is a tiger.
Schiller International University's main campus is in Largo.St. Patricks Catholic School has a campus on Trotter Road in Largo
column2: providing a private education for grades Pre-K to 8th grade. Other private schools in the city include Veritas Academy.

column1: Largo is served by two international airports
column2: Tampa International Airport and   St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport. St. Petersburg-Clearwater Airport is located about 6 miles (9.7 km) east of downtown. Tampa International Airport is located about 20 miles (32 km) east of downtown on the other side of Tampa Bay. The Pinellas Suncoast Transit Authority provides bus service throughout Pinellas County and express service to Tampa. State Roads 686 and 688 pass through Largo to connect with Interstate 275
column3: which connects with I-75.  US 19 and US 19 Alternate run north-to-south through Largo. A grid of county roads connects Largo with its neighbors.
